poem:
Election Morning

Under autumn's brittle light,  
fingers dance on paper and screen,  
a quiet torrent of ballots  
like leaves,  
or whispers in the chill—  
decisions pressed into an envelope,  
absent yet present,  
a weight measured  
in ink and resolve,  
dawn's promise held  
in each unspooling stroke  
of democracy's quill.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Voting is under way in the 2024 US election. Here’s what to know about early voting and mail-in ballots The US election is under way across the country, and so far more than 24.5m people have voted early, according to the University of Florida’s election lab. In numerous states, the push to vote before election day, whether by mail or in-person, has amounted to an unprecedented wave of early voting. More than 97,000 voted on". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
